desc.size: Shrub, 1 - 4 m tall, with ascending branches.

part.partText: yellowish green to reddish brown, hairy when young, becoming smooth.
reddish brown, egg-shaped, pointed, flattened, hairy, often appressed to the stem.

alternate, with 5 - 12 mm long leafstalks; dark green above, strongly bluish white-waxy beneath, 4 - 12 cm long, 1.5 - 6 cm wide, lanceolate to egg-shaped lanceolate, base rounded to heart-shaped, tip pointed, margins round to saw-toothed, teeth glandular, thick, smooth.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy, cylindrical catkins on short, leafy stalks; female catkins greenish, 2 - 8 cm long, scales dark brown, ovary hairless; male catkins white to silvery, 1.5 - 4 cm long, scales dark brown, stamens 2, filaments hairless, anthers purple turning yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in 4 - 8 cm long, elongated clusters; stalked, brown, 5 - 11 mm long, flask-shaped, smooth; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix myricoides var. myricoides is distinguished from all other shrub willows in the Chicago Region by having saw-toothed, hairless leaves that are strongly bluish white-waxy beneath. Leaf margins are flat, not revolute (down-curved).

speciesPage.flowering: Late April to early May, before or with the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Occurs on open sand, on calcareous pond shores, and in old sand pits near Lake Michigan. Beyond the lake it is occasional in fens.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Myricoides means “resembling Myrica.” Myrica derives from the Greek word for tamarisk, a shrub introduced from Eurasia.
